entity: Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)
entity_raw_name: 4.     Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)
source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.2_CLUSTER I_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A. 	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

On 14 December 2004, the Secretary-General appointed his Special Envoy for the implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004) to enable him to report to the Council every six months on the implementation of the resolution, as requested by the Council in its presidential statement of 19 October 2004 (S/PRST/2004/36).

In its resolution 1680 (2006), the Council reiterated its call for the full implementation of the provisions of resolution 1559 (2004), and strongly encouraged the Government of the Syrian Arab Republic to respond positively to the request made by the Government of Lebanon, in line with the agreements of the Lebanese national dialogue, to delineate their common border, especially in those areas where the border was uncertain or disputed.

In its resolution 1701 (2006), the Council emphasized the importance of the extension of the control of the Government of Lebanon over all Lebanese territory in accordance with the provisions of resolutions 1559 (2004) and 1680 (2006), and of the relevant provisions of the Taif Accords. The Council requested the Secretary-General to develop, in liaison with relevant international actors and the parties concerned, proposals to implement the relevant provisions of the Taif Accords and resolutions 1559 (2004) and 1680 (2006), including disarmament, and for delineation of the international borders of Lebanon.
In subsequent resolutions on Lebanon, the Council continued to urge all parties to make tangible progress towards all outstanding issues in the implementation of relevant Council resolutions.

In a statement by the President of the Security Council (S/PRST/2025/1) on 16 January 2025, the Council welcomed the cessation of hostilities between Israel and Lebanon of 26 November 2024 (S/2024/870). The Council called on the parties to fully implement the provisions of the cessation of hostilities understanding and for the full implementation of resolution 1701 (2006) and the Security Council’s previous relevant resolutions by all parties.

In 2016, the Under-Secretary-General for Political Affairs was tasked by the Secretary-General with assuming the responsibility of reporting on the implementation of resolution 1559 (2004), an arrangement that has been maintained to date.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this Mission contributes, is to ensure full implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004) and all subsequent related resolutions of the Council.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Mission will seek to use the present momentum to foster consensus on a Lebanese-led and Lebanese-owned national dialogue, which is expected to result in progress on addressing the maintenance of weapons outside State authority;

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in informed Security Council deliberations on possible opportunities for Lebanon to make progress on the outstanding provisions of Council resolution 1559 (2004).

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission coordinates with the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon, in particular in the process of developing the reports of the Secretary-General.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
The regional environment continues to affect Lebanon’s stability and security;

Following the 2025 presidential election and government formation, the ability of the Lebanese leadership to deliver reforms and tangible benefits for the population is put to the test, as they also face reconstruction challenges;

There is a greater political will by the Lebanese parties to address the disbanding and disarmament of Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias and some efforts towards that goal, though constraints persist;
International and regional Member States remain engaged in advancing the disbanding and disarmament of Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias;
Violations of Lebanese sovereignty and territorial integrity persist.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, through ensuring appropriate consultations with all stakeholders, including women leaders, and the inclusion of gender-disaggregated data, as appropriate.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission will support mitigating measures to overcome accessibility challenges, in addition to the efforts undertaken by relevant United Nations entities to ensure the accessibility of facilities, platforms, security and other infrastructure to facilitate easy access and use by persons with disabilities.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of resolution 1559 (2004)

The Mission undertook one trip to Lebanon in March 2024, which informed the drafting of the April 2024 report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of resolution 1559 (2004). However, a trip to Lebanon planned for September 2024 did not transpire due to a vacancy in the core capacity of the mission though the mission was able to deliver on planned results.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 15).
Table 15 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)
Understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)
Understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Informed Security Council deliberations through analytical reports of the Secretary-General – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The mission’s work contributed to informing Security Council deliberations on developments relevant to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Council resolution 1559 (2004). It met the planned target of Council discussions on the two semi-annual reports to reflect the outcome of consultations on the positions of Lebanese actors vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority.

In 2026, the mission will continue to report to the Security Council semi-annually on progress in the implementation of the resolution, in particular the disbanding and disarmament of Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias. The changed context in Syria may offer greater opportunities for progress in the implementation of the resolution 1680 (2006).
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson is that in-person consultations are necessary to identify opportunities for progress. In applying the lesson, the mission will further leverage engagement with United Nations entities both at Headquarters and in Lebanon, in addition to maintaining its network of interlocutors in the country.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 16).
Table 16 – Performance measure:

table_content.text: Discussions on the two semi-annual reports partly reflected the outcome of consultations on the positions of Lebanese actors, which were only partially articulated, vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority

Discussions on the two semi-annual reports, partly reflected the outcome of systemic consultations surveying the positions of Lebanese actors vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority
Discussions on the two semi-annual reports, partly reflected the outcome of systemic consultations on the positions of Lebanese actors vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority
Discussions on the two semi-annual reports, which reflect fully the outcome of consultations on the positions of Lebanese actors vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority
Security Council consultations account for the positions of Lebanese actors vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority

2.	Meetings of the Security Council on resolution 1559 (2004)

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 18 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 19 – Human resources
a	The Under-Secretary-General is on a $1-per-year contract.
b	Other level, unless otherwise stated.

The resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $430,900 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($372,700) for the continuation of three posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 P-4 and 1 General Service (Other level)), as well as operational costs ($58,200), comprising costs for official travel ($22,600), facilities and infrastructure ($30,500), and communications and information technology ($5,100).

In 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for international and national staff based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025.

The increase in requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable to the higher requirements for civilian personnel due to the application of a lower vacancy rate of zero per cent compared with the vacancy rate of 16.7 per cent applied in 2025. The increase is offset  in part by the application of the updated ICT standard rate and the removal of long-distance telephone service.
